keyword.name: 123crossword
keyword.exptext: A crossword variant in which 1, 2, or 3 letters may be written into each square. There are variations of this variant, which may allow different numbers of letters in the squares (such as the jumping crossword where 0 or 1 letters are allowed). When only a few squares contain multiple letters and the entries in those squares are related somehow, it is instead a rebus crossword.

keyword.name: 69lovesongs
keyword.exptext: (album by The Magnetic Fields)

keyword.name: a1b2
keyword.exptext: (In the 2004 hunt only, this commonly includes using mod 26 to reduce larger numbers)

keyword.name: adayinthelife
keyword.exptext: (an MIT photo-blogging project)

keyword.name: airportcodes
keyword.exptext: (IATA unless otherwise specified)

keyword.name: akarilightuppuzzle
keyword.exptext: The standard form of this puzzle consists of a grid where some cells are initially blacked in, and some of those contain numbers. To solve it, place lights (which illuminate all squares in a horizontal or vertical line from the light to the next black square or the edge of the puzzle) in some cells so that every square is illuminated by at least one light, no light is illuminated by another light, and the number of lights orthogonally adjacent to each number matches the number.

keyword.name: alphablock
keyword.exptext: The standard form of this puzzle consists of a square grid with a letter or group of letters in each cell. To solve it, spell words, phrases, or names reading left to right across the grid by taking one cell from each column. Each cell is used once. The items formed are members of some set or category, except for one answer which identifies the category.

keyword.name: alphacipher
keyword.exptext: The standard form of this puzzle type is a list of words, along with their values in a cipher which applies a different value from 1 to 26 to each letter of the alphabet, and adds up the values of the letters in each word. It's similar to an alphametic but there's no interaction of place value, and usually the whole alphabet is used.

keyword.name: alphameticsencodedarithmetic
keyword.exptext: These puzzles are essentially solved arithmetic problems (often long division or multiplication with all the partial products written out), with the entire problem encoded into letters with a simple substitution cipher. Sometimes the key (what 0123456789 encodes into) spells a final answer. A variant sometimes seen uses stars or blanks to indicate unknown digits.

keyword.name: alphasleuth
keyword.exptext: This puzzle type consists of a criss-cross-style grid with some letters pre-filled. There are exactly 26 unfilled spaces which need to be filled in using every letter of the alphabet once, forming words that have something in common. Some unfilled spaces have a number. A set of numbered spaces (possibly with repeats) below the grid uses the letters in the numbered grid spaces as a key, producing a final answer word or phrase.

keyword.name: americanfilminstitutestop100movieslists
keyword.fullname: American Film Instutute's top 100 movies lists

keyword.name: americathebookacitizensguidetodemocracyinaction
keyword.fullname: America (the Book): A Citizen's Guide to Democracy Inaction

keyword.name: anguishedenglish
keyword.exptext: (a.k.a. Anguish Languish; heavily distorted homophones of sentences)

keyword.name: animalsontheundergroundwebsite
keyword.fullname: Animals on the Underground web site

keyword.name: answergivenforcompletingtask
keyword.exptext: (These puzzles do not clue their answers; you get the answer after doing something the puzzle somehow asks you to do. See also creative tasks and intermediate tasks)

keyword.name: backandforthpuzzletype
keyword.exptext: In the standard form of this puzzle, a grid is provided that has spaces for three letter groups to be entered on alternate sides of a central axis. The answers are six letters long, using two consecutive groups, and read in alternating directions, so that each answer begins with the last three letters of the previous answer, reversed. Standard crossword-like clues are provided.

keyword.name: balancepuzzle
keyword.exptext: The standard form of this puzzle includes a set of two or more hanging beams marked off in equally spaced intervals, with weights and/or other beams hanging at some of the marked points. This structure, a bit like a mobile, is meant to balance by the torque rule - for each beam, the sum of (weight x distance to fulcrum) for all weights on one side of the fulcrum equals that sum for the other side, the fulcrum in this case being the point the beam hangs from. The beams themselves are weightless but convey the total weight of the weights they hold to the beam they hang from. The values of the weights must be filled in from a predetermined set, usually 1 to N where N is the number of weights.

keyword.name: bananagrams
keyword.exptext:
Bananagrams is one of many fast-paced word-building games which all use the following general rules:
  • Each player draws some set number of tiles from a large supply at the start of the game.
  • At a signal, all players flip over their tiles and try to arrange them all into a legal Scrabble board. All letters must be used to form words, all the words must interlock into a single network, and all groups of adjacent tiles must form words reading left to right or top to bottom.
  • The first person who succeeds in doing this calls out some signal (like "Draw!") at which point each players draws two (or only one, in some games) more tiles from the supply.
  • All players rebuild their layouts to incorporate the new letters. You can rearrange the letters arbitrarily, but you are going to be faster if you can just add the tiles as a new word or extend an existing word.
  • The first player done calls out and more tiles are drawn.
  • Repeat until there are not enough tiles remaining for everybody to draw new tiles.

keyword.name: basesotherthanten
keyword.exptext: (see also binary/biliteral/Baconian cipher and ternary cipher )

keyword.name: battleshipspuzzle
keyword.exptext: The standard form of this puzzle consists of a grid with numeric clues outside the grid and possibly parts of the solution given inside the grid. You have to locate a fleet of ships (usually 1 of length 4, 2 of length 3, 3 of length 2, and 4 of length 1) in the grid, such that no two ships occupy adjacent cells (even diagonally) and the number of occupied cells in each row and column matches the given number. Givens may appear as a circle (length 1 ship), square (interior piece of a length 3 of longer ship), half-square-half-circle (end of a length 2 or longer ship), or wavy lines (no ship).

keyword.name: beforeandafter
keyword.exptext: This is like the Wheel of Fortune category, where two phrases overlap by a common word. This is distinguished from word chains because here the parts are whole words or names and usually in short chains of 2 or 3 phrases (3 or 4 parts).

keyword.name: bifidcipher
keyword.exptext: The bifid cipher is a cipher based on taking indexes into a 5x5 square of letters, but instead of turning the text into numbers, the numbers are read in a different order and converted back to letters through the square. The link explains in more detail.

keyword.name: binarybiliteralbaconiancipherany5bitbinaryforletters
keyword.fullname: binary/biliteral/Baconian cipher (any 5-bit binary for letters in alphabetical order)

keyword.name: birdsofamerica
keyword.exptext: (John James Audubon book)

keyword.name: blackboxgame
keyword.exptext: Black Box is a puzzle-like game where one player tries to determine the locations of hidden atoms in a grid by observing how the atoms reflect rays entering the box from various locations. It can also be solved as a puzzle, given a predetermined set of ray results.

keyword.name: blackboxsolvermustfigureoutinnerworkings
keyword.fullname: black box (solver must figure out inner workings)

keyword.name: blindness
keyword.exptext: (Puzzles where you have to do something blindfolded or in the dark.)

keyword.name: bongardproblems
keyword.exptext: (Given two sets of items, what feature is shared by all the items in one set and none of the items in the other?)

keyword.name: bookcode
keyword.exptext: A type of cipher where a book or other widely available text is used as a key, and the message is encoded as a series of numbers which are indexes into the text. Indexes may be single (word or letter counts in the entire text) or multiple (indexing first by page, then by word, or first by word, then by letter, etc.) This is sometimes called a Beale cipher, in reference to a famous one which used the U.S. Declaration of Independence as a key.

keyword.name: building1656floorcode
keyword.exptext: The code is apparently 6 bit binary with 0=A, 1=B, ..., two characters per column, and boustrophedonic (direction of columns alternate). Codes above 25 are defined as various symbols, but not used here.

keyword.name: building2mathematicalmodels
keyword.exptext: (a display case on the first floor)

keyword.name: building56murals
keyword.exptext: Four panels in MIT's building 56, each 6 squares wide and 8 squares tall, with some of the squares containing pictures or text.

keyword.name: burrpuzzles
keyword.exptext: These are physical puzzles where a set of solid pieces must be assembled so that the pieces interlock and form some tight shape (or alternatively, disassembled from that solved state). The traditional form consists of six 2x2x6 blocks with various cubes or other parts cut out of their middles, with a solution where two pieces run lengthwise along each of three perpendicular axes. Other forms of puzzles based on interlocking polycubes are sometimes included in this category.

keyword.name: calllettersoftvorradiostations
keyword.fullname: call letters of TV or radio stations

keyword.name: cambridgehistoricalcommissionsblueovalhistoricmarkers
keyword.fullname: Cambridge Historical Commission’s blue oval historic markers

keyword.name: cartoonrebuses
keyword.exptext: Cartoon rebuses are a type of puzzle made popular during the contest craze of the early 20th century and revived in Games Magazine. A single black and white comic-style scene conceals a name or phrase by breaking it up into parts which combine, phonetically, as in a rebus (but without subtraction) to form the answer phrase. Each part is depicted in the cartoon, possibly as a word in a dialogue, a letter on a shirt, a pictured object, or something strongly implied by the scene. These parts are hidden among other irrelevant bits to make a comic scene. A category and the enumeration of the letters in each word of the answer is given.

keyword.name: cashcab
keyword.exptext: (TV game show)

keyword.name: charades
keyword.exptext: Any sort of cluing words by parts, such as automobile + domestic animal = floor covering (car + pet = carpet). It may or may not be phonetic. It may or may not include cluing by gestures as in the parlor game of this name.

keyword.name: chiptunes
keyword.exptext: Retro electronic music which mimics the sound of early home computer and video game audio systems.

keyword.name: cityaddressgrids
keyword.exptext: Some cities, or parts of cities, have a rectangular grid of streets, with the street names in one or both directions being sequential numbers or letters, and often with the addresses matching cross-streets (so the addresses on a street between the intersections with 5th and 6th streets would be between 500 and 600). Although the distance between each pair of streets is not always the same, this provides opportunities to interpret the map as a Cartesian plane.

keyword.name: communitysolarsystemexhibitofthemuseumofscience
keyword.fullname: Community Solar System (exhibit of the Museum of Science)

keyword.name: consonantcies
keyword.exptext: Puzzles where words share the same consonants in the same order, with any vowels.

keyword.name: corralpuzzle
keyword.exptext: The standard form of this puzzle is a grid with numbers in some cells. A single closed loop is to be drawn along the edges of the grid so that all the numbers are inside the loop, and the number of squares in the row and column through each number, going up to the first part of the loop encountered in each direction, and counting the cell with the number once, equals the number.

keyword.name: crackedmagazine
keyword.exptext: Cracked is online

keyword.name: creativetasks
keyword.exptext: (Build, write, or perform something, instead of solving a puzzle. Does not count those puzzles where you have to do some small thing at the end, but see answer given for completing task and intermediate tasks for those)

keyword.name: creekpuzzle
keyword.exptext: Creek is a Nikoli logic puzzle type. A grid contains circled numbers at some of its intersections. Blacken some squares so that of the 4 squares around each number, that number of squares are black, and so that the empty squares form a single orthogonally connected group.

keyword.name: crisscross
keyword.exptext: In its standard form, this puzzle consists of a loosely interlocking grid and a list of words to be filled in. You must use logic and elimination to figure out where to place the words. See also disconnected criss-cross and diagramless criss-cross. This category includes puzzles where the word list is clued rather than provided, but if the clues are associated with specific entries, this becomes a crossword puzzle instead.

keyword.name: crossnumberpuzzle
keyword.exptext: This is a crossword puzzle where the answers are numbers written with digits. These puzzles are usually full of cross-references and clues which limit their answers to certain subsets of integers, and usually follow the rule (as in many numerical puzzles) leading zeroes are not allowed.

keyword.name: crossproductscrosssumsvariant
keyword.exptext: This is like a Cross Sums except the product of the digits in each entry is given, rather than the sum.

keyword.name: crosssumskakuro
keyword.exptext: This is one of the most popular numerical puzzle types. In its standard form, a crossword-like grid has clues in the grid providing the sum of the digits to be entered in each entry. No zeroes are used and no entry contains any digit more than once.

keyword.name: crosswordpuzzles
keyword.exptext:
The standard American-style crossword puzzle, occasionally with a more open-form grid than usual. See crossword variants for those where words are entered in unusual ways, and cryptic crosswords for puzzles with cryptic or British-style cluing.

Modern crossword puzzles sometimes include one of a number of tricks, and naturally these show up in hunts as well. Among these are the rebus crossword in which more than one letter is written into a few squares of the crossword, and deletion or letter change themes in which the theme entries are modified in some way to fit into the grid.

keyword.name: crosswordvariants
keyword.exptext:
Puzzles with crossword-like cluing and intersecting/overlapping words, but not in the traditional crossword fashion. Standard variants included within this keyword include:
  • jumping crossword
  • marching bands
  • pathfinder
  • petal puzzles
  • Right Angles
  • Some Assembly Required
  • spirals
See also forms and double crostic.

keyword.name: crypticcrosswordclues
keyword.exptext: (cryptic crossword clues whose solutions do not go into a grid)

keyword.name: crypticcrosswords
keyword.exptext: The standard British-style crossword or cryptic crossword, where clues usually consist of a straight definition and a wordplay clue concatenated in either order. This category includes cryptic double-crostics and the like, but see cryptic crossword clues for puzzles where the clues stand alone and their answers do not go into some sort of grid.
keyword.puzlink: (sort of; answers are all fish and clues wordplay-only)

keyword.name: cryptograms
keyword.exptext: (all simple substitution ciphers, but see alphametic for cryptic math puzzles)

keyword.name: cuttingoutshapes
keyword.exptext: (most, but not all, of these involve cutting out shapes to fold into 3-dimensional figures)

keyword.name: dancing
keyword.exptext: These puzzles also appear under their specific dance names, for example, square dancing, ballroom dancing, and swing dancing.

keyword.name: deletionsandinsertions
keyword.exptext: (includes curtailments and beheadments, and some deletions of multiple letters)

keyword.name: devilsdictionarythe
keyword.exptext: A book containing satirical definitions of words, written by Ambrose Bierce, first published in the early 20th century, collecting his newspaper columns from the late 19th century.

keyword.name: diagnosticandstatisticalmanualofmentaldisorders
keyword.fullname: Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders

keyword.name: diagonalizing
keyword.exptext: (reading an answer from a series of words by reading the first letter of the first, second letter of the second, etc.)

keyword.name: diagramlesscrisscross
keyword.exptext: There are two standard versions of this puzzle. In one, you're given one starting word in a big open grid, and you are given not only the word list but also the list of words that cross each word, in order. In the other, you're given the word list, and the grid is pre-filled with all occurrences of one or more letters which are frequent in the word list (sometimes rebus-style, with a word of two or more letters written into the pre-filled cells, though the other squares are normal).

keyword.name: diagramlesscrossword
keyword.exptext: A crossword puzzle for which the grid is not given. In the standard form, the American crossword standards are enforced rigidly; there are no unchecked letters or two-letter words and the grid has 180-degree rotational symmetry. Numbers are sequential in lexical order.

keyword.name: dimensionadded
keyword.exptext: (any puzzle that takes a standard puzzle type and adds more dimensions than it usually has)

keyword.name: disconnectedcrisscross
keyword.exptext: This puzzle contains multiple criss-cross grids with just two words in each. Some additional relationship is necessary to constrain which two words cross in each grid.

keyword.name: dominopuzzle
keyword.exptext: (divide the grid into a set of dominoes)

keyword.name: doublecrostic
keyword.exptext: In the standard form of this puzzle, clue answers are written on a set of numbered blanks, then transferred into a grid where words (usually spelling a quotation) read only across, wrapping around the ends of rows. Normally, each number appears only once among the answers and the grid contains the letter of the clue which uses that number, so that you can also work from the grid back to the clues. The initial letters of the answers, in clue order, spell out the source of the quotation (sometimes abbreviated).

keyword.name: drawinglettersandnumbers
keyword.exptext: (Any puzzle where the solution provides lines or a matrix of pixels that form letter and number shapes.)
keyword.puzlink: (sort of; instead of the usual way, they are clued by adding or removing letter parts)

keyword.name: dropquotes
keyword.exptext: In the standard form of this puzzle, a grid is given with black squares to separate words (which otherwise wrap around the ends of rows), and the letters that go in each column are given, in alphabetized or scrambled order, above that column. The solution is a quotation (whose source is usually not given in the puzzle).

keyword.name: duckkonundrum
keyword.exptext: (see also following directions for similar non-Duck-Konundrum puzzles)

keyword.name: eggcorns
keyword.exptext: Eggcorns are words or phrases that come to exist when people mishear or misunderstand other phrases. Eggcorn is itself an eggcorn of "acorn." The same phenomenon is called a Mondegreen when it occurs in song lyrics.

keyword.name: electricalengineering
keyword.exptext: (mostly analyzing circuit diagrams)

keyword.name: endviewpuzzle
keyword.exptext: This is a kind of Latin square puzzle in which each row is to be filled with the same set of different letters and some number of blank spaces. Outside the grid, clues indicate the first non-blank at that end of that row or column.

keyword.name: equationanalysistest26linthea
keyword.fullname: Equation Analysis Test (26 = L. in the A.)

keyword.name: events
keyword.exptext: All teams come together for something that only happens once.

keyword.name: eventsmultiple
keyword.exptext: In the following events, teams interact with each other, but the event is staged multiple times as needed.

keyword.name: externalpublicationsandbroadcasts
keyword.exptext: (these puzzles make use of material that the constructing team got published, or aired on radio/television, somewhere outside the Mystery Hunt, then referenced in a puzzle)

keyword.name: eyeofargonshortstory
keyword.fullname: "The Eye of Argon" (short story), Eye of Argon (short story)

keyword.name: eyerhymevisuallysimilarnonrhymingwordpairs
keyword.fullname: eye rhyme (visually similar non-rhyming word pairs)

keyword.name: fencespuzzle
keyword.exptext: In the standard form of this puzzle (also called slither link and many other names) a single closed loop is to be drawn along the grid lines, so that the number of sides of each numbered square used in the loop equals the number in that square.

keyword.name: feynmandiagrams
keyword.exptext: Feynman diagrams are representations of the interactions of subatomic particles.

keyword.name: fillapix
keyword.exptext: This is a logic puzzle very much like the Minesweeper game but all the clues you are going to get are provided initially, and spaces with clues may also contain mines (in which case they include themselves in their count). Puzzles without this self-counting behavior are classified under Minesweeper instead.

keyword.name: fillominopuzzle
keyword.exptext: The standard form of this puzzle consists of a grid where some cells initially have a number. To solve it, fill numbers into the remaining cells so that each orthogonally connected group of the same number consists of as many cells as that number. There may be zero, one, or more than one number given for each group.

keyword.name: findthelist
keyword.exptext: (puzzles where a key step in the solution is to find a well-known list of items given the lengths or similar information)

keyword.name: firstandlastlettersofwords
keyword.fullname: first and last letters of words

keyword.name: flatsnplpuzzles
keyword.exptext: These are verse puzzles where the answers are words with some sort of wordplay relationship, and they are missing from the verse (typically replaced by other all-caps words, the cue words, which, when necessary, explain which word goes where).

keyword.name: fleschkincaidgradelevel
keyword.exptext: (a measure of the "grade level" of a piece of writing)

keyword.name: followingdirections
keyword.exptext: (see also Duck Konundrum)

keyword.name: formswordsquaresandothers
keyword.exptext: Forms are small crossword-like puzzles with grids in simple geometric shapes. Today, in English, these are almost exclusively found in the National Puzzlers' League, with the exception of common types like word squares.

keyword.name: funnyfarm
keyword.exptext:
The original Funny Farm is a game of graphical Word Association. Associated words are linked by a line, and all the words related to one that you have solved are indicated with boxes to be filled in. Due to there being many paths, you can sometimes get multiple clues to narrow down difficult words.

The first attempt to reproduce this in the Mystery Hunt was a puzzle called Funny Farm in 2011 that overloaded the Hunt server and had to be replaced by a backup puzzle.

keyword.name: gamblinggames
keyword.exptext: (see also specific games)

keyword.name: gemcraft
keyword.exptext: (tower defense video game)

keyword.name: godelescherbachaneternalgoldenbraid
keyword.fullname: Godel, Escher, Bach: An Eternal Golden Braid

keyword.name: harvardsentences
keyword.exptext: (a set of sentences used to measure the quality of an audio signal)

keyword.name: hashiwokakero
keyword.exptext: The standard form of this puzzle consists of a set of circled numbers aligned to a grid (which is not otherwise given). To solve it, add some horizontal or vertical "bridges" between the circled numbers such that the number of bridges terminating at each number is the same as that number. At most two bridges may extend in each direction from a number, and bridges never intersect or jump over numbers.

keyword.name: heteronyms
keyword.exptext: Heteronyms are words that are spelled the same but have different pronunciations and meanings. They are the opposite of homophones, and are a subset of homographs (which are words with the same spelling and different meanings, but not necessarily different pronunciations).

keyword.name: heyawake
keyword.exptext: This puzzle consists of a grid with heavy outlines dividing it into a set of rectangular regions of various sizes. Some of the individual cells are to be shaded, such that no two adjacent cells are ever shaded, all the unshaded cells form a single orthogonally connected group, and in regions with a clue number, the number of shaded cells equals that number.

keyword.name: hiddenpuzzle
keyword.exptext: A puzzle which is hidden inside another puzzle or in an unexpected place where solvers do not expect to find puzzles.

keyword.name: hiddenwords
keyword.exptext: Generally, this puzzle type works like the hidden word style of cryptic crossword wordplay: Answers appear among consecutive letters of words in a phrase, ignoring word boundaries and punctuation, as WORD appears in new order.

keyword.name: hillwords
keyword.exptext: Hill words have letters in alphabetical order up to a point, then in reverse alphabetical order for the rest of the word.

keyword.name: hitori
keyword.exptext: The standard form of this puzzle consists of a grid initially filled in with a number in every cell. Some of these cells are to be shaded such that no two adjacent cells are shaded, all the unshaded cells form a single orthogonally connected group, and no two unshaded cells in the same row or column contain the same number.

keyword.name: ibeforeeexceptaftercexceptions
keyword.fullname: i before e except after c exceptions

keyword.name: identifytextfromstresspatternprosodyorpoeticmeter
keyword.fullname: identify text from stress pattern, prosody, or poetic meter

keyword.name: ihtfp
keyword.exptext: IHTFP is an acronym for I Hate This F**king Place, coined at MIT decades ago, and often referenced by forming original backronyms for the five letters.

keyword.name: informationmissing
keyword.exptext: Parts of these puzzles are missing from the archive. Please contact the current Mystery Hunt team if you have information to add.

keyword.name: insultswordfighting
keyword.exptext: (from the Monkey Island games)

keyword.name: intermediatetasks
keyword.exptext: These puzzles do not directly clue their answers. They give you a task to complete, and when that is done, you are given another puzzle which does clue the answer. See also creative tasks and answer given for completing task.

keyword.name: isawyoumit
keyword.exptext: The web site isawyou.mit.edu, a "missed connections" web site just for the MIT community.

keyword.name: jigsawpuzzles
keyword.exptext: (most of these are reconstructions of an image divided into rectangular pieces, rather than traditional jigsaw shapes)

keyword.name: jigsawquote
keyword.exptext: The standard form of this puzzle consists of a 16x16 grid divided into 4x4 sections, into which a quote is to be written, with words wrapping around the ends of lines and black squares separating them. The letters to be filled in are provided, but the words and part-words within each 4x4 block are provided in sorted order, and the resulting groups are also provided in sorted order. Usually the different black squares in different sections distinguish most, but not all groups, and likewise the unique lengths of some letter strings within their groups allow some strings to be placed uniquely. Beyond that you have to figure out how to fit things so that they spell words.

keyword.name: jumblepuzzle
keyword.exptext: This puzzle, which is syndicated in many newspapers, consists of a set of scrambled words and a row of boxes to enter each one in, some of them containing circles. The circled letters can themselves be anagrammed to form a final answer, usually a punny punch line to complete the joke caption for an accompanying cartoon image.

keyword.name: jumpingcrossword
keyword.exptext: The jumping crossword is usually not a crossword in the conventional sense at all, since the word list is given. It's more like a criss-cross puzzle but with the extra rule that some squares will be left blank, with words simply reading across whichever letters are used (as opposed to a diagramless crossword where the unused squares mark word break). If there are black squares, they separate entries in the same row or column. In the original logic puzzle type jumping crossword, blank squares are not allowed to touch along an edge.

keyword.name: kenken
keyword.exptext: The standard form of this Latin square puzzle consists of a grid divided into a number of heavily outlined regions, each of which contains a small clue number and a mathematical operation. The grid is to be filled in with the numbers from 1 to N, not repeating a number within a row or column, such that the result of applying the operation in each region to the numbers filled into that region equals the clue number.

keyword.name: keyboard
keyword.puzlink: (qwerty, Colemak, and symbols on shifted letters)
(qwerty, dvorak, and layouts for various languages)

keyword.name: kingofkongafistfulofquarters
keyword.fullname: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters

keyword.name: knightstour
keyword.exptext: As a purely mathematical puzzle, this is simply a challenge to cover each square of a grid once with a series of knight moves (as in chess). But more commonly this same sort of knight's tour occurs on a grid pre-filled with letters, so that words are spelled out along the path.

keyword.name: languages
keyword.exptext: (see also invented languages)
keyword.puzlink: (Klingon, Dutch, Tocharian A, Esperanto, Tagalog, German, Welsh, Catalan, Anglo-Saxon, Latin, Norwegian, Greek, Thai, Chinese)
(Basque, Romanian, Korean, Italian, Albanian, Estonian, Turkish, Burmese, Swedish)
(Spanish, Welsh, French, Latin, Esperanto, Hungarian, Slovak, Dutch, Greek, Japanese, Catalan, Russian, Hindi, Portuguese, Polish, Chinese, German, Korean, Turkish, Italian)
(numbers in Financial Chinese, Javanese, Thai, Tibetan, Tengwar, Mayan, Lao, Arabic, D'ni)
(Arabic, Bengali, Czech, Danish, Esperanto, French, German, Hebrew, Italian, Japanese)
Ancient Greek, Chinese, Farsi, French, German, Hebrew, Inuit, Japanese, Latin, Spanish, Swedish, toki pona
(Portuguese, Russian, Persian, German, Arabic, Thai, Hebrew, Japanese, French, Bulgarian)

keyword.name: lastwords
keyword.exptext: The last words spoken by people before they died

keyword.name: latinsquares
keyword.exptext: A Latin square is simply one where the same set of letters, numbers, or other symbols appear in each row and each column. A number of standard puzzle types (see End View, KenKen, skyscrapers, star battle, and sudoku) are based on forming a Latin square under additional constraints, and those puzzles are listed under those categories.

keyword.name: letteradjacencygraphs
keyword.exptext: The letters in some text are nodes in a graph, and each pair of letters which occurs consecutively in that text is connected by an edge (directed or undirected). See also Namystics.

keyword.name: letterbanks
keyword.exptext: A letter bank is the set of letters that appears in a word, with all duplicates removed, especially when these letters are anagrammed to spell another word. This category includes puzzles where each letter is given or used only the first time it appears in some answer, even though this does not spell a word.

keyword.name: letterchanges
keyword.exptext: (many variations are included here, but see also misspellings)

keyword.name: lettereddice
keyword.exptext: In the standard form of this puzzle, you are given a set of 4-letter words (containing, collectively, 24 different letters) which have been rolled using a set of 6-sided dice with different letters on each side. You have to determine which letters appear on each die.

keyword.name: letterlinks
keyword.exptext: What is the correct name for this puzzle type? It is the one where a list of related words must be discovered, where a set of boxes is given for each word, and between each pair of consecutive words in the list, all repeated letters are connected by lines.

keyword.name: liarlogicpuzzlesandselfreferentialstatementsetc
keyword.fullname: liar logic puzzles (and self-referential statements, etc.)

keyword.name: lifecellularautomaton
keyword.puzlink: (also Life cereal, Life magazine, Hasbro's Game of Life)

keyword.name: linkapix
keyword.exptext: Link-a-Pix is a puzzle type invented by Conceptis. A grid contains scattered numbers in various colors. Like numbers are to be connected using orthogonally connected paths which don't overlap, each as long as the number they connect, and colored the same as the numbers they connect, with the result forming a picture.

keyword.name: literature
keyword.exptext: (All novels, stories, plays, children's books, etc., regardless of their literary value)
keyword.puzlink: (America (the Book): A Citizen's Guide to Democracy Inaction)
(On Beyond Zebra and various Dr. Seuss titles)
(The Restaurant at the End of the Universe)

keyword.name: litspuzzle
keyword.exptext: LITS is a Nikoli logic puzzle type. A grid is initially divided into several heavily outlined regions. Within each grid you must blacken 4 squares forming one of the tetromino shapes L, I, T, or S such that no 2x2 grid section is completely blackened (thus, the O tetromino is not allowed), all the tetrominoes form one orthogonally connected group, and no two tetrominoes of the same type touch along an edge.

keyword.name: logicpuzzlebasedonelimination
keyword.exptext: This is the logic puzzle with wordy clues and usually the big grid used to keep track of which identifiers (names, pets, colors, whatever) can or cannot belong to each other. The grid may or may not be given.

keyword.name: magnetlogicpuzzles
keyword.exptext: In the standard form of this puzzle, a grid is broken up into 2-cell regions, some of which are to be filled in with a + in one cell and a - in the other, so that the total number of +s and the total number of -s in each row and column equal the numbers given outside the grid, and two of the same symbol are never in orthogonally adjacent cells.

keyword.name: marchingbands
keyword.exptext: In this crossword variant, clues are given for two or more words which are entered directly after one another in each row, without black spaces, and another set of clues are given for words entered similarly in concentric bands indicated by shading and a letter where each band starts. If the size of the grid is odd, the center square is usually black and, in that row only, the black square separates the two words written there.

keyword.name: masyu
keyword.exptext: In the standard form of this puzzle, a grid is provided with empty or filled circles in some cells. A single closed loop is to be drawn through some cells so that the loop passes through every circle, turning in each filled cell (but not turning just before or after the filled circle), and going straight through empty circles (but turning before and/or after the empty circle).

keyword.name: mathmaze
keyword.exptext: Math maze is a path puzzle with Battleships-style clues that tell you how many squares in each row and column are part of the path. This makes it a relative of the snake puzzle but in math mazes only the head and tail are given and the path is allowed to visit squares adjacent to other parts of the path. The grid may have holes which divide rows and columns into parts; in this case clues apply to each part separately. Random Walk contains an example puzzle.

keyword.name: mazes
keyword.puzlink: (following twisty lines that do not branch)

keyword.name: mirrorlogicpuzzles
keyword.exptext: In the standard form of this puzzle, you have to determine where to place two-sided mirrors at either or two diagonal directions in some cells, so that each pair of identical clues outside the grid is connected by a path of orthogonally connected cells through the grid which bends at (and only at) mirrors, in the directions which do not cross the mirrors. A path may use the same cell twice (either passing straight through an empty cell twice in different directions, or bouncing off both sides of the same mirror)

keyword.name: mitbrassrats
keyword.exptext: This refers to the designs on MIT class rings (which feature their mascot, the beaver).

keyword.name: mitbuildingnumbers
keyword.fullname: MIT building numbers and room numbers

keyword.name: mithenge
keyword.exptext: MIThenge is an even that occurs each year when the sun aligns with the Infinite Corridor.

keyword.name: mithistorymuralinkendallstation
keyword.fullname: MIT history mural in Kendall Station

keyword.name: mooninitesadvertisingaquateenhungerforce
keyword.fullname: Mooninites advertising Aqua Teen Hunger Force

keyword.name: multiplecrosswordsolutions
keyword.exptext: Crossword-like puzzles where the same clues and grid have multiple solutions, as opposed to Siamese Twins where there are two different clues for each space.

keyword.name: musicidentificationfromaudiosamples
keyword.puzlink: (audio samples performed live at event by Hunt organizers)

keyword.name: musicsheetmusictranscriptionsofnotesorsolfege
keyword.fullname: music (sheet music, transcriptions of notes, or solfege)

keyword.name: mysteryhunt
keyword.puzlink: (answer to another puzzle in this Hunt)

keyword.name: nameoftherosebyumbertoeco
keyword.fullname: The Name of the Rose by Umberto Eco

keyword.name: namystics
keyword.exptext: Namystics are a puzzle type similar to letter adjacency graphs in that the letters of a name are connected in order, but any enclosed regions are filled in, hiding some of the lines. This name for the puzzle was used in Games Magazine.

keyword.name: narrativecharts
keyword.exptext: (as in this xkcd strip)

keyword.name: nim
keyword.exptext: Nim is a mathematical game. The basic version has several piles of chips, and each player in turn picks any pile and removes one or more chips from that pile (including possibly taking the whole pile). There are many variations of the game and a whole area of mathematics based on finding the best strategies for these games.

keyword.name: norinoripuzzle
keyword.exptext: Norinori is a Nikoli logic puzzle type. A grid is initially divided by heavy borders into a number of regions. Within each region, blacken two squares so that every black square shares an edge with exactly one other black square (not necessarily in the same region).

keyword.name: numbersassociatedwithorinwords
keyword.fullname: numbers associated with or in words

keyword.name: nurikabe
keyword.exptext: This is the most common "island" puzzle. In the standard form, a grid is provided with numbers in some cells. Some of the unnmubered squares are to be shaded so that the shaded squares form a single orthogonally connected group, and each orthogonally connected group of unshaded cells contains exactly one number, which is the size of that group.

keyword.name: offline
keyword.exptext: (Events where team members are brought somewhere to solve puzzles without electronic assistance)

keyword.name: onetimepadorgronsfeldcipher
keyword.fullname: one-time pad, Gronsfeld cipher, or Augustus cipher

keyword.name: onetimepadusedmultipletimes
keyword.fullname: one time pad used multiple times

keyword.name: orderinglogicpuzzles
keyword.exptext: (given a list of actions, put them in the only logically consistent order in which they could take place)

keyword.name: paintbynumberslogicpuzzle
keyword.exptext: In the standard form of this puzzle, a large empty grid is provided, along with a set of clue numbers on each row and each column. Some cells are to be shaded so that each row or column contains groups of shaded cells, separated by one or more blank cells, with the lengths of these groups matching the provided clue numbers, in order. There are common variants where cells may be shaded in different colors or half-shaded with triangles; in these variants, the different colors or triangles in each row are normally given in the clues, and the requirement of a blank cell between groups is waived if they are different types, or any types of triangles.
keyword.puzlink: variant, using lengths of lines between lattice points

keyword.name: pangrams
keyword.exptext: A pangram is text that contains every letter of the alphabet.

keyword.name: paragraphpuzzles
keyword.exptext: (as the term is used on Grey Labyrinth - you have to figure out the secret rule that determines what words or sentences are valid)

keyword.name: party
keyword.exptext: (Puzzles where you have to get information at the traditional party, usually on Friday evening)

keyword.name: pathfindercrossword
keyword.exptext: A crossword variant in which words may meander around the grid on orthogonally connected paths. Conventionally, each square is used in exactly two entries. The Pipe Dream crossword is a variation on this where additionally each edge between squares is crossword once, and the words can be colored red and black so each letter is part of one red and one black word.

keyword.name: pathpuzzles
keyword.exptext: There are many other standard puzzle types which are path puzzles, where the point of the puzzle is to determine a path through a grid from given clues. This puzzle type is used for ones that don't fit into any of the standard types.

keyword.name: pentominominesweeperlogicpuzzle
keyword.exptext: This is a variation on the standard Minesweeper puzzle type where the mines are forced to lie in groups of 5 orthogonally connected mines, usually all different and without the groups touching, even diagonally.

keyword.name: phoneticlettersandnumbersnvenvyorsingleletters
keyword.fullname: phonetic letters and numbers (NV = envy or single letters)

keyword.name: phoneticpuzzles
keyword.exptext: (phonetic versions of puzzles commonly based on letters rather than sounds)

keyword.name: phraseswithasetofwords
keyword.fullname: phrases with a set of words

keyword.name: pictactoe
keyword.exptext: Pic-Tac-Toe is a puzzle type from the early days of Games Magazine in which a 3x3 grid of pictures is provided and you have to determine the common theme in each line of three pictures.

keyword.name: playingcardscodeassigningletterstospecificcards
keyword.fullname: playing cards code (assigning letters to specific cards)

keyword.name: polcarisitalianrestaurantintechsquare
keyword.fullname: Polcari's Italian Restaurant in Tech Square

keyword.name: portmanteaus
keyword.exptext: A portmanteau is the combining of two words or phrases by taking part of each to make a new word or phrase. Commonly, the beginning of one word is welded onto the end of another word in a portmanteau.

keyword.name: printersdevilry
keyword.exptext: (This is sort of the opposite of the hidden word type of Cryptic Crossword clue. Sentences that make a sort of half-sense are given; they make better sense when a word is inserted somewhere within the sentence, possibly changing word breaks and punctuation.)

keyword.name: programminglanguages
keyword.exptext: (see also esoteric programming languages and perl)

keyword.name: punsandanagramscrossword
keyword.exptext: This crossword variant usually uses a standard American-style grid, but the clues are neither standard American-style nor British-style. Instead, each clue either clues the answer in a punny way, or contains an anagram of the answer within the clue (not segregated from the clue with an anagram indicator as in anagram cryptic crossword clues).

keyword.name: quotesquare
keyword.exptext: In the standard form of this puzzle type, you get a grid with three letters in each square, with clues for words to be eliminated, one letter per box, in a row or column for you to determine, with the remaining letters (one per box) spelling a message.

keyword.name: railfencecipher
keyword.exptext: The rail fence cipher, also called zigzag cipher, is a particular transposition cipher where a message is encoded by writing it in a zigzag pattern across the page, then reading the letters row by row.

keyword.name: railroadcrossingpuzzle
keyword.exptext: The standard form of this puzzle consists of a grid with the numbers 1 to N in some squares and crosses in some other squares. You must draw a path through all squares in the grid, going through the numbered stations in order and going straight at each station, and only crossing itself at the marked crosses.

keyword.name: realmenofgeniusbudlightadcampaign
keyword.fullname: Real Men of Genius (Bud Light ad campaign)

keyword.name: rebus
keyword.exptext: The most common kind of rebus is the one from the Concentration game show: A word or phrase is clued, partially or completely phonetically, via a series of smaller words, with plus and minus signs indicating how to combine the parts; they are combined in order, so the material to be removed by a minus part must exist in the result of the operation immediately before the minus sign. Any manipulation of words involving both adding and subtracting parts is classified here; for ones where parts are only added, see charades.

keyword.name: rebuscrossword
keyword.exptext: A crossword puzzle in which more than one letter is to be written into some spaces, the rebus squares. Usually all the rebus squares are the same sequence of letters, or they are related somehow. Usually there are only a few of these (less than 5%), though they are not necessarily limited to long theme entries; if many squares contain multiple letters and there's no theme to those squares, it is a 1, 2, 3 crossword. The letters in rebus squares are usually meant to be read the same way across and down. This gimmick is usually not clued; solvers have to figure it out while solving.

keyword.name: restaurantattheendoftheuniverse
keyword.fullname: The Restaurant at the End of the Universe

keyword.name: reversals
keyword.exptext: words or phrases that are reversed by letter, sound, or word

keyword.name: reversewordsearch
keyword.exptext: (The puzzle where you are given the words and have to figure out how to fit them into the mostly blank grid in straight lines, and variations.)

keyword.name: rightanglespuzzle
keyword.exptext: A crossword variant where words may read in any of the four orthogonal directions, and each answer takes a 90-degree turn somewhere in the answer (for you to determine).

keyword.name: rivercrossinglogicpuzzles
keyword.exptext: This is for variations on the classic puzzle where a farmer is trying to cross a river with a wolf, a goat, and a basket of cabbages. He can't leave the wolf unattended with the goat, since it will eat the goat, nor can he leave the goat unattended with the cabbages, but his boat can only carry one of the three things besides himself. Even classically there are many variations on this.

keyword.name: roadkillbuffet
keyword.exptext: Improv show formerly held at MIT on Saturday night during Mystery Hunt.

keyword.name: roadrallye
keyword.exptext: A road rallye is a puzzle that takes place either on real roads or virtually, via a map, with a complicated series of instructions that may involve standing conditionals (from now on, if this ever happens, do that), different levels of instructions with a designated order of precedence for deciding what to do when different instructions conflict, and other trickery.

keyword.name: rollingstones500greatestsongsofalltime
keyword.fullname: Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Songs of All Time

keyword.name: rowsgarden
keyword.exptext: This crossword variant contains a grid of triangular cells. The standard grid size has a broken row of 9 spaces at the top and bottom, and every other row contains 21 spaces. The triangles are shaded in groups of 6 into hexagons (roses or blooms) of three different colors, no two same-colored hexagons touching. Clues are given for one word in each short row and usually exactly two words across each long row, and for the 6-letter words in each bloom. You must determine both the starting point and direction for the blooms, as well as which word goes into each bloom. The bloom clues are sorted by bloom color, and usually alphabetically by answer within each color.

keyword.name: scattergories
keyword.exptext: In Scattergories, you are asked to think of items that belong to various categories beginning with specific letters of the alphabet.

keyword.name: scytale
keyword.exptext: The scytale is a cipher where a narrow ribbon is wrapped around some cylindrical object and a message is written across the windings of the ribbon rather than along it. The right size cylinder (or a lot of patience) is required to decipher it.

keyword.name: shiftingletters
keyword.exptext: (like Caesar ciphers or Vigenere, but with separate shifts provided for every letter)

keyword.name: shikaku
keyword.exptext: In the standard form of this puzzle, you must divide the given grid along the grid lines into rectangles so that each rectangle contains exactly one of the given numbers, which is the area of its rectangle.

keyword.name: siamesetwinspuzzle
keyword.exptext: The standard form of this puzzle is a crossword with two identical grids and two clues at each number. You have to figure out which clue goes with which grid, i.e., which clues lead to words that interlock in the same crossword.
keyword.puzlink: (variant; only Across clues given for one puzzle, only Down clues for the other)

keyword.name: skyscraperspuzzle
keyword.exptext: In the standard form of this Latin square puzzle, you must fill in the numbers 1 to N in the cells of the NxN grid so that no number is repeated in a row or column. Additionally, if the numbers are taken as the heights of buildings, the numbers outside the grid tell how many buildings can be seen in that row or column from that side of the grid, where taller buildings hide shorter buildings that are behind them.

keyword.name: slidepuzzle
keyword.exptext: One of the standard puzzle types with this name is one like the 15 puzzle, where a set of square blocks are able to slide around in a frame which has a hole exactly as large as one of the pieces, and the object is to get the pieces into some sort of order. There are also similar puzzles (sometimes called sliding block puzzles) in which the hole may be two or more cells in size, and the blocks may be more than one cell also; in this type, often the object is to get one particular block to a particular location.

keyword.name: snakepuzzle
keyword.exptext: The standard form of the snake puzzle contains a single snake whose segments are numbered 1 to N, of which certain segments are filled in initially, including the head and tail. The snake cannot touch itself, even diagonally (only squares with consecutive numbers may be orthogonally adjacent, and only ones with numbers that differ by 2 may be diagonally adjacent). Clues indicating the number of snake segments in certain rows and columns are are given. Black squares indicating spaces the snake cannot pass through may be given.

keyword.name: snakevideogame
keyword.exptext: Snake is a classic video game where you direct the head of a snake to eat food in marked locations within a grid. Each time the snake eats, it gets longer. When the snake runs into another part of its body, the game ends.

keyword.name: solitairehangmanpuzzle
keyword.exptext: This is a hangman game designed for you to play without direct interaction by the word-chooser. The number of letters is given, and a pair of lookup tables provide a way for you to check whether and where in a word a particular letter appears, without spoiling yourself by seeing the results of nearby letters.

keyword.name: solutionmissing
keyword.exptext: The solutions for these puzzles are missing. Please contact the current Mystery Hunt team if you have the solution.

keyword.name: someassemblyrequired
keyword.exptext: In the standard form of this crossword variant, clues are given for two or more words that read across each row, without any black spaces between them, and for a set of snaky jigsaw pieces, where the clue for each piece is given but you must determine how to arrange the pieces to fill the grid.

keyword.name: songswithlists
keyword.exptext: The order of the items in the list may be important as an indexing or ordering mechanism in puzzles that use songs with lists.

keyword.name: soundex
keyword.exptext: Soundex is an algorithm for very loosely classifying words phonetically based on their initial letter and consonant pattern.

keyword.name: spellingoutletters
keyword.exptext: Spelling out names of letters, like ay, bee, see.

keyword.name: spiralpuzzle
keyword.exptext: In the standard form of this crossword variant, a set of clues is given for words to be entered from 1 to 100 along the spiral, without skipping any spaces, and for another set of words to be entered from 100 to 1. Thus, the second set of answers is collectively a reversal of the first set of answers.

keyword.name: splitdecisionspuzzle
keyword.exptext: This is the standard puzzle type where you have to fill in a criss-cross style grid with words you have to figure out on your own, based on bigram changes where both versions of the changed letters are given beside each other in the grid.

keyword.name: sports
keyword.exptext: (see also specific sports: baseball, basketball, bowling, boxing, cricket, football, golf, soccer)

keyword.name: starbattlelogicpuzzle
keyword.exptext: The standard form of this puzzle works as follows: A square lattice is divided into irregular polyomino regions. Enter some stars so that each row, each column, and each region contains exactly two stars, and no two stars are adjacent, even diagonally.

keyword.name: statueparkpuzzle
keyword.exptext: Statue Park puzzles are an original invention of Palmer Mebane. A set of polyominoes are to be placed into a grid. They can touch at a corner but not along an edge. The unused space must form a single edge-connected unit. Black circles must be covered by polyominoes; white circles must not.

keyword.name: stereograms
keyword.exptext: Stereograms are pairs of images intended to be viewed one with the left eye and one with the right eye while focusing so that the two images appear to lie in the same space. Small differences in the images create the illusion that some parts are above or below other parts. In the 1990s there was a popular series of what are called autostereograms - single images with repeating patterns that create the same sort of illusion; this is what usually appears in puzzles.

keyword.name: subwaythetorothercitiessystems
keyword.fullname: subway (the T or other cities' systems)

keyword.name: sudokunumberplace
keyword.exptext: In the standard form of this puzzle type, a 9x9 grid is divided into 3x3 sections with heavy bars. The grid is to be filled with the digits 1 to 9 (some initially provided) so that no number is repeated in a row, column, or outlined region. There are popularly many variants on this puzzle type, including ones where the diagonals have to contain 1 to 9, ones where the regions are not square, ones where there are restrictions on which numbers can be adjacent, and many others.

keyword.name: tangibleobjectsgiventoteams
keyword.exptext: In most cases, these tangible objects will not be available to those solving old Hunts from the archives, though sometimes electronic reproductions of them are possible.

keyword.name: tangrams
keyword.exptext: A classic puzzle consisting of 7 pieces, where the challenge is to form them into various shapes. The unit cell for these pieces is a 45-45 right triangle; two of the pieces consist of a single unit cell. One of the pieces is a square made of two unit cells, one is a triangle of two cells, one is a parallelogram of two cells, and the last two pieces are triangles made of 4 unit cells each.

keyword.name: tapa
keyword.exptext: In the standard form of this puzzle, a grid is provided with one or more numbers in some cells. To solve it, shade some empty cells in an orthogonally connected group so that among the 8 cells orthogonally or diagonally adjacent to each numbered cell, the connected group(s) of shaded cells have the size(s) of the number(s) in that cells. (Like paint by numbers except the clues apply to these 8-cell rings instead of rows and columns.)

keyword.name: telephoneexchangewordslike55klondike
keyword.exptext: (see also phonespell)

keyword.name: telephonegame
keyword.exptext: Telephone is a traditional game in which one person tells a secret to another, and that person repeats it to a third person, and so on. The final person reveals what they were told and the players find humor in how the message mutated in retelling.

keyword.name: tetcbnanswerappearsaspartofpuzzle
keyword.fullname: TETCBN (answer appears as part of puzzle)
keyword.exptext: In the National Puzzlers' League, the phrase The Error That Cannot be Named is used in errata to say that the answer, or part of the answer, appears in the puzzle, without giving away what that answer is. In the Mystery Hunt this technique is used on purpose once in a while.
keyword.puzlink: (the answers to the clues appear elsewhere in the puzzle)

keyword.name: thermometerslogicpuzzle
keyword.exptext: In the standard form of this puzzle, a grid is provided filled with thermometer shapes (ovals which lie within a single row or column, with a bulb at one end). Shade in some cells, but within each thermometer, only a connected group starting at the bulb, so that the number of shaded cells in each row and column matches the clues outside the grid.

keyword.name: tiltmazes
keyword.exptext: The standard type of this puzzle is a mechanical puzzle where you have to maneuver a ball through a maze, trying to get it from a starting point to a goal, without falling through any of the other holes in the maze. You can only manipulate the ball by tilting the entire maze, using gravity to move the ball.

keyword.name: timesequencepuzzles
keyword.exptext: (putting pictures in chronological order based on clues in the pictures)

keyword.name: timevaryingpuzzles
keyword.exptext: (when you reload the puzzle later you get something different)

keyword.name: tomswifties
keyword.exptext: A Tom Swiftie is a pun involving a quotation from a character usually named Tom, which is followed by a dialogue tag of the form Tom said ___ly. The pun is that the adverb chosen is appropriate in some way to the message he said.

keyword.name: towerofhanoi
keyword.exptext: The Tower of Hanoi is a classic puzzle with a set of disks of different sizes and 3 posts on which to place the disks. In the standard form of this puzzle, you are asked to move the entire stack from one post to another, but you can only move one disk at a time, and you can never place a bigger disk on top of a smaller disk.

keyword.name: transdeletionsandtransadditions
keyword.exptext: A transdeletion is a combination of deletion and anagram, deleting one letter from a word and rearranging the rest to spell another word. A transaddition is the opposite operation.

keyword.name: transpositioncipher
keyword.exptext: This is any kind of cipher where the identities of the letters remain intact, but they are arranged into a different order. There are many names for specific variations of this cipher, but a typical case is for a text to be split into a number of equal rows, then read down the columns.

keyword.name: tribond
keyword.exptext: The object of Tribond is to determine the common bond between three given things. For example, if the clues were crossword, jigsaw, and sudoku, the answer would be puzzle.

keyword.name: trigrams
keyword.exptext: Although trigrams can refer to any manipulation of groups of three letters, there is a common puzzle type where you have to unscramble and reassemble messages which have been broken up into trigrams after removing any spaces and punctuation. If the message does not have a multiple of three letters, the final one or two letters are typically left as they are and placed at the end of the list of trigrams (which is typically alphabetized). In other cases the message(s) may be crafted to have a multiple of three letters so that there is no leftover.

keyword.name: tvshows
keyword.exptext: (see also cartoons)

keyword.name: valleywords
keyword.exptext: Valley words have letters in reverse alphabetical order up to a point, then in alphabetical order for the rest of the word.

keyword.name: viewsofasolidobject
keyword.exptext: These are the 2-dimensional forms that appear when you view a solid object from different sides. It may be based on the overall shape of the object, or on markings on or inside the object.

keyword.name: voyagergoldenrecord
keyword.exptext: the golden records sent into space aboard the Voyager spacecraft

keyword.name: wackywordies
keyword.exptext:
Wacky Wordies are an old Games Magazine feature. Words or phrases are clued in which part of the answer suggests a way to write letters, and the remaining part of the answer is written in this way. It is possible that those letters are written in two or more groups whose relationship is indicated by the unwritten words. For example:

STAND

I


represents "I understand."

keyword.name: wallywoods22panelsthatalwayswork
keyword.fullname: Wally Wood's 22 Panels that Always Work

keyword.name: washingtonnationalpresidentsrace
keyword.exptext: An event at Washington Nationals home baseball games.

keyword.name: wheeloffortune
keyword.exptext: This puzzle type is named for the game show, and is based on the idea of being able to guess some puzzles immediately, with no letters in it, based only on the lengths of the words and the punctuation provided. Various kinds of clues may accompany the blanked-out messages.

keyword.name: whereintheworldiscarmensandiego
keyword.fullname: Where in the World is Carmen Sandiego?

keyword.name: wordchains
keyword.exptext: (the end of one word overlaps the beginning of the next; see before and after when the overlapping parts are words)

keyword.name: wordfunctions
keyword.exptext:
Discovering operations that convert a word or string of letters to a different one.
One puzzle type that relies on this displays a series of clues, each of which has been modified by some rule. When you determine the answer to the clue, it has to be modified in the same way to make another word.

keyword.name: wordladders
keyword.exptext: A word ladder is a series of letter changes with the goal of getting from one word to another, with each step forming a valid word.

keyword.name: wordplayother
keyword.puzlink: (this is based on an uncommon but standard puzzle type, but I don't know its name)

keyword.name: wordsearch
keyword.exptext: The standard word search is a grid of letters, within which a provided list of words is hidden, each one in a straight line in one of 8 directions (orthogonally or diagonally). Frequently the unused letters spell a final message.

keyword.name: wordsonwindingpaths
keyword.exptext: (word searches that can change direction, or a whole quote spelled in this way)

keyword.name: wordstack
keyword.exptext: A word stack is a grid for a list of related words arranged so that some matching letters fall in the same columns; these letters get a single tall box to indicate the repetition. The words may be arbitrarily staggered left or right, and sometimes arbitrarily ordered, in order to increase the number and height of these shared letter boxes. Usually only a few letters are initially given.

keyword.name: xzibit
keyword.exptext: Xzibit is the celebrity associated with the Internet meme "Yo dawg, I heard you like X so I put a X in your X so you can Y while you Y." It's based on his time as host of the MTV television series "Pimp My Ride" in which he said similar things about what he had installed in cars (where the last X was usually "car" and the last Y was usually "drive"). The meme version makes all the Xs the same, so that you're putting something inside itself, or another of the same thing.

puzzle.name: mit199400
puzzle.exptext: The New York Times crossword which the puzzle references is also posted on the Hunt Web site.

puzzle.name: mit199402
puzzle.exptext: This puzzle involved telnetting into some computer that was set up during the Hunt. We don't know what sort of puzzle was involved there. But since it was set up on port 1729, and 1729 is the Hardy-Ramanujan number, the smallest number expressible as the sum of two positive cubes in two different ways (12<SUP>3</SUP>+1<SUP>3</SUP> = 10<SUP>3</SUP>+9<SUP>3</SUP>), it may well have been math related.

puzzle.name: mit199403
puzzle.exptext: This is really a different type of puzzle than the quote square, but I don't know the name for it.

puzzle.name: mit199415
puzzle.exptext: This puzzle has an error. The given letter R and the shaded square above it should both be one row lower.

puzzle.name: mit199500
puzzle.title: 0: Newspaper Archives
puzzle.exptext: If anybody has copies of the newspaper elements used in this puzzle, they would make a great addition to the archive.

puzzle.name: mit199502
puzzle.title: 2: Screening Room
puzzle.exptext: This is a variant of the standard letter links type; links are provided sporadically, and sometimes between nonadjacent pairs, while video images of the characters were provided.

puzzle.name: mit199503
puzzle.title: 3: Conservatory
puzzle.exptext: Diagramless variant of jigsaw quote, where the black squares are not given. As an aid to solving, the groups of word parts are sorted by which columns they fall into.

puzzle.name: mit199508
puzzle.title: 8: Dining Room
puzzle.exptext: The end of the maze in the archive is cut off from a fax copy, and since this conceals which paths at that end are connected, as well as some of the connecting warp letters, it's not possible to solve the part that remains.

puzzle.name: mit199510
puzzle.title: 10: Study
puzzle.exptext: The entire puzzle is missing. This was first MIT Mystery Hunt puzzle delivered via a web site, though (perhaps simply due to availability of a server) that site was at Stanford. However, no known copy of the puzzle is available.

puzzle.name: mit199512
puzzle.title: 12: Screening Room
puzzle.exptext: This puzzle was provided on a videotape which is not in the archive. However, since its answer is a US state capital spelled backward, it can be assumed that the list to be completed was US state capitals spelled backward, or pronounced as if they were spelled backward.

puzzle.name: mit199514
puzzle.title: 14: Conservatory
puzzle.exptext: The solution is mostly there, but it doesn't seem to spell anything. There may be an error in the solution, or in the puzzle.

puzzle.name: mit199725
puzzle.title: Elvis to Lip-Sync Hole; Ranting Courtney Love Vows She'll Sue!
puzzle.exptext:
The shapes of the top rows of letters in each block make it appear that they should be concatenated into a single long block. Then the gaps in the top row can be filled in with letters to spell a series of clues:

Adding with jam and bread; no one under seventeen admitted without parent or guardian; first letter of third s?i?n?l?h?b?t?r?a?c?n

So we have peanut butter, R (or R-rated), and some instruction in the part where we only have every other letter which I have not fully solved. And then there are the second lines, which do not look like English. It doesn't even look like a cryptogram of English; the distribution of letters is rather flat: UEAWWYDAILCBAEQSPWXTQOAADJBKMYZVTJHOPJYCQYFNXCSKLUZEXGF YBEXMXCWFKPJXNSGLRJLNUSCNNSALCZXLKXKBPBQXKZBNKIGEVGHRQS

puzzle.name: mit1999dossiers
puzzle.title: Dossiers (Meta)
puzzle.exptext: There are 12 of these dossiers, corresponding to the 11 warrants in later parts of this hunt, with all dossiers and solutions linked from the indicated page, plus Carmen Sandiego. Each one is a mini-meta corresponding to some of the answers in the round where that crook's warrant is issued, and sometimes ones from previous rounds. Carmen's dossier is slightly different, and it ties into The Final Meta.

This audiotape seems to have Row, Row, Row Your Boat (whose sheet music was provided) played with an odd variety of different instruments. Presumably we are supposed to identify them.

puzzle.name: mit2008d41
puzzle.title: Instant Replay
puzzle.exptext:
This puzzle is missing a detailed solution on the Mystery Hunt web site, so here goes!

Each paragraph is a description of part of the action that might take place in a particular pinball game, as clued by the used of the word replay in the title.

  1. NORTH CAROLINA AVENUE. This is Monopoly, but the pinball's version of the board omits the utilities and all the non-property spaces except the first community chest and last chance, changing the outcome of a roll of 8 from Indiana. The cop target blocks access to the shot that allows you to roll and advance on the board.
  2. ORLANDO. This is World Cup Soccer. There are eight cities on the World Cup tour in the game, ending in LA, and after Boston and New York is Orlando.
  3. TRAP DOOR. This is Theatre of Magic. The four misses hit the trap door targets on either side of the center ramp, lighting Raise Trap Door on the ramp. Hitting the trap door gives a random basement award, one of which advances the clock directly to midnight.
  4. AMY. This is Congo.
  5. NEVER ENDIN' BIKE SUCKIN' SWAMP. This is Blackwater 100. There are eight sections to a lap, including the swamp with this sign, and the other seven are clued as having been completed.
  6. ORION. This is Transporter: The Rescue. The ship is the U. N. Orion.
  7. TED. This is Road Show. Again you're trying to get to Los Angeles, this time on a course that visits 18 cities. Ted is one of two big heads on the playfield, with a bulldozer blade sometimes blocking access to his mouth.
  8. HIDEOUT JACKPOT. This is High Speed (not High Speed II, which starts multiball after the initial red light run).
  9. EXCELLENT RAY. This is Dr. Dude. The Magnetic Personality, Heart of Rock and Roll, Gift of Gab, Mixmaster, and Excellent Ray are shots you need to start Multiball. After multiball ends, all scores are doubled until the end of the ball.
  10. ROOF. This is WhoDunnit?. I know it sounds like a game of Clue. This is probably intentional in the design of the pinball.
  11. DEAD HEADS. This is Elvira and the Party Monsters (not Scared Stiff, which has more dead heads; also in Elvira you are specifically waking them).
  12. AGAINST THE ROPES. This is Champion Pub.
  13. MEADOWLANDS. This is Sopranos.
  14. NEW TICKET. This is Jolly Park, easily the most obscure pinball machine used in this puzzle, but the clue that it's from Spain helps you find it.
  15. ASSAULT. This is Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines. The female antagonist is the best clue that this is not Terminator 2. The last Command Centre award is Assault.
  16. COMIC BOOK GUY. This is The Simpsons: Pinball Party.
  17. RODNEY. This is Surf 'n' Safari (not Whitewater, which is not really zoo-themed).
  18. ORTHANC. This is Lord of the Rings.
  19. NO WAY OUT. This is Whitewater. No Way Out is the lock shot.
  20. YELLOW BELLY. This is Banzai Run. The first four riders you have to pass, who may be passed in any order, are Green Machine, Blue Beard, Yellow Belly, and Red Hot. Only after passing them can you challenge the King of the Hill for the win.
  21. MAGNA-SAVE. This is Black Knight 2000 (not the original Black Knight, which doesn't say those things, though both have Magna-Save).
But it is the names of the features that go in the blanks, not the games, that matter. Their initial letters spell NOT ANOTHER DAMN ACRONYM, which is ironically abbreviated on the internet as NADA, which is the answer.
puzzle.author: Bowen Kerins
Trip Payne

puzzle.name: mit2010r041983m
puzzle.title: Round 4 Meta
puzzle.exptext: This round purported to be the 1983 MIT Mystery Hunt, long missing from the archives. It turned out that the 1983 Hunt had been in the archives all along, but mislabeled as the 1982 Hunt, due to the first three Hunts not having years printed on them, and an error from an old article about the Mystery Hunt that wrongly gave 1980 rather than 1981 as the year of the first Hunt. Brad Schaefer, the creator of these early Hunts, set the record straight.
puzzle.author: Nathan Fung

puzzle.name: mit2012a2
puzzle.title: I Can Hear You
puzzle.exptext: In this event, teammates went to opposite sites of the Lobdell dining hall, each with a cell phone, and one had to communicate messages received on their phone to the other person without using the phone. The teammate had to then enter this message correctly on his phone.
